title: 103_s1599
content: The Act may be cited as the "Missing and Exploited Children Task Force Act of 1993". The Congress acknowledges the widespread victimization of children in the nation, with alarming statistics on child abductions and runaways. Local law enforcement agencies often lack the necessary resources to address these crimes effectively, especially considering that a majority of police departments have limited personnel. Locating missing children requires a coordinated law enforcement effort. Supplementing local agencies with a team of assigned Federal agents will allow pooling of resources and expertise to assist in investigating difficult cases involving missing children. The Act aims to establish a task force of law enforcement officers to collaborate with the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in assisting State and local authorities with investigating challenging cases of missing and exploited children. This task force will be created under Title IV of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. The Missing and Exploited Children's Task Force is established under Title IV of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. It includes members from various law enforcement agencies and is led by a representative from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Missing and Exploited Children's Task Force, established under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974, is led by the Director of the FBI. The Task Force members are law enforcement personnel selected for their expertise in investigating cases involving missing and exploited children. Members are chosen by the Task Force chief from a list provided by agency heads. The Missing and Exploited Children's Task Force, established under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974, is led by the Director of the FBI. Task Force members serve for a period of 1 year, with the possibility of renewal for an additional year. The chief of the Task Force can request replacements to maintain a capable membership. The Administrator of the General Services Administration provides support in coordination with agency heads. The Missing and Exploited Children's Task Force, led by the FBI Director, is provided office space and administrative support services in close proximity to the Center. The Attorney General assigns a US Attorney to offer legal guidance as needed. The Task Force's purpose is to utilize resources and expertise to aid in challenging missing and exploited child cases nationwide. The Missing and Exploited Children's Task Force, under the FBI Director's leadership, assists in child cases nationwide by providing technical assistance, resources, and training to its members. The Attorney General cross-designates Task Force members for their roles in investigations. The Attorney General cross-designates Task Force members with jurisdiction to enforce Federal law related to child abduction to accomplish the purposes of this section.
